refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: ardj is a collection of tools that can be used to run a full featured fully automated internet radio station. It is designed to stay alive even when there's nobody looking for it from the administrative point of view: bad music will go away, fresh music will be found, as long as listeners care.

ardj uses an SQLite database to store the runtime data, a tiny web server to access it, an XMPP (Jabber) bot for runtime management and to interact with the audience, and a plugin which feeds ices.Â The web server which is used as the database interface is built on web.py and requires zero configuration; it's main purpose is to prevent deadlocking the SQLite database by synchronizing multiple processes accessing it.
Buzzword bingo: streaming, MP3, SQLite, Jabber, robotics, Last.fm, Libre.fm, scrobbling, jingles, prerolls.
This document is a work in progress. The complete documentation is available on the website.

refsect1.title: Setting up a station
refsect1.para: To run a streaming radio station you will need the following components: icecast2, ices and ardj.

Icecast2 is the multiplexor, it has little brain. Its main job is to receive a stream from a source (ices) and retransmits it to as many listening clients as there are. It's like a proxy for multimedia streams. It is a separate product and has nothing to do with ardj.

Ices is the stream source. It reads file names from a playlist, loads and decodes the files, cross-fades them nicely, encodes the result to the configured format (typically MP3) and sends the result to icecast. This is also an independent component that has little to do with ardj. It only uses the playlist plugin which ardj provides to read file names from the database instead of flat files.
ardj is the virtual brain of your radio station. It maintains playlists, picks the music and jingles, collects feedback from the audience, adjusts track priorities and so on.

refsect1.title: Command line options
refsect1.para: The first parameter to ardj is the command. Some commands require additional arguments, they are described below.

listitem.para: Looks for audio files in the incoming_path folder. What's found is moved to the database, source files are deleted. If the source can't be deleted, it's ignored (to prevent adding it multiple times).
Only files with extensions .mp3 and .ogg are added, other files are ignored.

When the files are imported, artist names and track titles are read from the metadata, other common tags are ignored. One uncommon tag which is used is ardj: with it you can preset track labels. Example format: "ardj=1;labels=music,rock" (this is the value, including the "ardj=1" prefix, which designates metadata format).
This is similar to the jabber command upload.
Opens the configuration file for editing with your default editor. The editor name is read from the EDITOR environment variable. If there's nothing, the editor command is used.
Opens the database console. This is useful if you need to perform some low-level operations and don't want to type the full database path.
This command only works if you have sqlite3 installed.

Initializes the database structure by creating tables and indexes which are missing. This command is normally used by the installation script only. You might only need to use it if you deleted the database file and want to create a new one from scratch.
Removes dead data from the database. Dead data is labels that are no longer used and files which correspond to deleted tracks.
Shows brief database statistics, e.g.: "2883 tracks, 192.0 hours".
Schedules retrieving more tracks by the specified artist. This only adds a request to the database, without immediately downloading anything.
This is similar to the jabber command download.

Starts searching for new music. It first selects artists that have tracks rated above average, then looks for their music on Last.fm and Jamendo. Tracks which can be downloaded and which aren't in the database are downloaded and added to it.

Looks up all artists in the Last.fm database and corrects their names when necessary. This usually implies case correction, but can sometime change the name completely (which is still correct unless Last.fm fails drasticly).
You typically run this command on a nightly basis.
Shows a help screen similar to this manual.

Marks approximately 10 best tracks which have the "music" label with the "hitlist" label. The number of tracks can be higher than 10 if there are many tracks with weight equal to track number 10 (i.e. they all share 10th place)..

Applies label "label" to tracks that are liked by all specified users. One typical use is when you have an upcoming live show with multiple hosts and you want to play music that they all like, to adjust the mood of the audience.
Marks tracks longer than average with the "long" label. You can use it to remove those tracks from daily rotation or something like that.

Marks tracks that don't belong to a playlist with the "orphan" label. This can help you find blind spots in your playlists. If you want to prevent some special tracks (with special labels) from being marked as orphans, just create a playlist for them (the one below the default playlist, which will actually never be used).
Merge votes from aliases defined in the jabber/aliases config parameter. This command should be used after you edit the list of aliases.
Delete everything from the manual playlist (see the queue jabber command).

Starts the Web API server, which typically listens to localhost:8080. This server is used by the ices plugin to get names of files to play and by the jabber bot to perform some actions. Normally you don't start the server manually, unless you want to debug it; normally it's started by the ardj-server upstart job, e.g.: sudo start ardj-server.
Send the specified message to Twitter. Only works if you have the twitter config file parameter set up properly, otherwise it'll tell you how to do that.
Shows recent messages which mention your Twitter account. Not really useful.

Looks up Last.fm for upcoming concerts by artists which have tracks rated above average. Saves the data to a JavaScript file named in the event_schedule_path, which can be used to display a Google map on your web site. Also, all tracks by artists which have upcoming concerts are marked with the "upcoming-concert" label, so that you could add some prerolls or change the rotation priority.
Only works if you configured the Last.fm integration properly.
Updates track lengths stored in the database with real values from the files. This is useful if you change files in the musicdir folder manually, or if you had a failure and resorted to backups.
Updates real track weights according to user votes.
Sends the specified message to the specified recipient. If the recipient jid was not specified, the message is sent to the chat room (named in the jabber_chat_room configuration parameter).

refsect1.title: Jabber commands
refsect1.para: These commands must be sent to the jabber bot directly. Some commands require special privileges, see the jabber_admins config parameter.

listitem.para: Adds a track to the manual playlist, which have the highest priority.

refsect1.title: Configuration
refsect1.para: There is one configuration wile which contains all settings.Â This file is named /etc/ardj.yaml, if you're installing system wide, or $HOME/.config/ardj/ardj.yaml if you're testing locally.

listitem.para: This option defines the folder where the music will be stored. Files in this folder have scrambled names, related to the file contents' MD5 checksum, e.g. 2/4/24a141bfaaae48969901a9ab1206dc76.mp3. This is not a publicly accessible folder, you should not try to do anything with the files in it. To add new music, add it to the folder specified with the incoming_path parameter.
Default location is /var/lib/ardj/music.

This parameter defines the folder where you should put music that you want to add to the database. This folder is typicalliy made available over ftp or sftp.Â After copying files to this folder, send the upload command to the jabber bot.

When files are added to the database, only two common tags are read and used: "artist" and "title". One uncommon tag is "ardj", with which you can preset internal metadata, such as labels. Syntax example: "ardj=1;labels=music,rock" (normally you only set the labels this way, other options are currently ignored).
Default location is /var/lib/ardj/incoming.

With this parameter you can set default labels for new files. This typically has labels which will later help you find unsorted music and label it properly. If you have a playlist for incoming unsorted music, you can also specify it here.
